description:
Beatragus hunteri, commonly known as the Hunter's antelope or the Hirola, is a critically endangered species of antelope found in the Horn of Africa region. It is the sole living member of the genus Beatragus, which is believed to have diverged from other bovid lineages during the late Miocene or early Pliocene period.

The Hirola is a medium-sized antelope, characterized by its distinctive appearance. It has a stocky build, with a short neck and relatively small, rounded horns that curve slightly backward. The species exhibits a distinctive facial pattern, with a prominent white blaze on the forehead and a black stripe running from the eye to the corner of the mouth. The coat color is generally a reddish-brown, with white patches on the belly and the inner surface of the legs.

Hirolas are primarily grazers, feeding on a variety of grasses and other herbaceous vegetation. They typically live in small herds, ranging from a few individuals to several dozen, and exhibit a complex social structure involving cooperative behaviors and hierarchical relationships.

The conservation status of the Hirola is a significant concern, as the species has faced severe population declines due to factors such as habitat loss, poaching, and competition with livestock. Ongoing conservation efforts, including habitat management, anti-poaching patrols, and captive breeding programs, aim to protect this unique and endangered species from further decline.
